title: Cat. 27  Denarius (Coin) Portraying King Ancus Marcius, 56 B.C.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Denarius (Coin) Portraying King Ancus Marcius  
56 B.C., issued by Roman Republic, L. Marcius Philippus (consul)  
Silver; diam. 1.8 cm; 4.19 g  
Mint: Rome  
Obverse: Head of Ancus Marcius, diademed, right; lituus behind  
Inscribed: ANCVS (below)  
Reverse: Equestrian statue, right, atop aqueduct  
Inscribed: PHILIPP[VS] (outward); AQVA MAR (in arches of aqueduct)  
RRC 425/1; axis: 4:00  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Martin A. Ryerson, 1922.4848

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">In 56 B.C., the ghost of monarchy hung sulkily in the air above Rome. The triple alliance of Pompey, Julius Caesar, and Crassus in 60 B.C. had accelerated their high-handed and often illegal maneuvers to muzzle opposition, while each warily watched the others for signs that one was about to make a run for supreme rule and leave the others behind. Caesar continued his wildly successful campaign to conquer Gaul, making Pompey jealous of his achievements and popularity.

In this year, the consul L. Marcius Philippus, who had married the widow Atia, a niece of Julius Caesar, struck this coin. The obverse bears the diademed head of Philippus’s ancestor Ancus Marcius, the fourth king of Rome. The lituus, or augur’s staff, behind him may refer to a relative who held that position.

The remarkable reverse illustrates one of the earliest aqueducts of Rome, the Aqua Marcia (fig. 27.1), traditionally said to be built by that same king but in fact built circa 144 B.C. by a more recent ancestor, Quintus Marcius Rex, whose cognomen refers to his descent from a king. The moneyer’s own cognomen Philippus curls at the edge of the coin, and an equestrian statue puns on that name, “lover of horses” in Greek; but the repetition of the family name Marcius in the arches of the aqueduct makes sure that no one can miss the royal forebear and recall what a great benefit he brought to the city of Rome. Philippus, a master of realpolitik, may have sensed that very soon his wife’s uncle would be king in all but name. He surely had a profound influence on his wife’s son by an earlier marriage, Octavian, who would end the Republic that had originated as a rejection of monarchy.  
Theresa Gross-Diaz

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">In the Republic, not only the three official moneyers could strike coinage—consuls and generals of provinces could do so as well.

The diadem is the ancient headwear of royalty in the Greek and early Roman world. Iconographically it was associated with Alexander the Great and connoted absolute monarchy. What we think of as a crown today, the spiky radiate crown, is associated with the Sun and is used only rarely before the third century A.D. See Stout, “Jewelry as a Symbol of Status.”

The early kings are known to us mostly through legends; Ancus Marcius is said to have lived in the late seventh century B.C.

It was the third aqueduct in Rome, funded by the recent conquests of Carthage and Corinth. It remained the longest ever built in Rome, at 91 kilometers, and was in use until the tenth century A.D.

See Gray-Fow, “Stepfather’s Gift,” esp. p. 194.
